thread.section_title: Times-standard.com covers local news in Humboldt County, California. Keep up with all business, local sports, outdoors, local columnists and more.
thread.title: Weekend storm expected to flood coast, knock out power
thread.title_full: Weekend storm expected to flood coast, knock out power

author: Jackson Guilfoil
title: Weekend storm expected to flood coast, knock out power
text:
Latest Headlines Weekend storm expected to flood coast, knock out power Share this: Click to share on Twitter (Opens in new window) Click to share on Facebook (Opens in new window) Click to print (Opens in new window) Parts of the Humboldt Bay, such as King Salmon, saw flooding on in 2022. The storm forecast this weekend will likely flood low-lying communities like King Salmon and the Arcata Bottoms. (HCSO/Contributed) By Jackson Guilfoil | jguilfoil@times-standard.com | Eureka Times-Standard UPDATED: December 12, 2024 at 3:59 PM PST The National Weather Service issued a flood watch for Humboldt County’s coastline and within interior, and southern regions in anticipation of this weekend’s storm.
The storm, expected to begin Friday morning, will bring strong winds and significant rainfall which, in tandem with king tides, presents a good chance of flooding communities like King Salmon and the Arcata Bottoms. The coasts could see 3 to 5 inches of rain, but the county’s inner ridges could see up to 8 inches of rain alongside snow on state Route 299. Winds were forecast to bluster at enough speeds to down trees and take out powerlines.
“The winds will die down fairly fast, so power outages will likely not last super long, hopefully, fingers crossed,” Jacob Boomsma, a meteorologist at the National Weather Service office in Eureka said.
Winds around the coast are expected to blow from 45 to 50 miles per hour along exposed headlands, but Humboldt County’s elevated ridges near Kneeland or the King Range could see wind speeds clear 60 miles per hour.
The Eel River at Fernbridge and Mad River are at the monitor stages, not quite reaching flooding, but rivers will certainly rise with the incoming rains.
The baseline high tide around Humboldt Bay is 8.5 feet, but the king tides are pushing it higher, signaling the beginning of the annual floods in King Salmon and the Arcata Bottoms. By Thursday, the tide reached 9.2 feet, and Boomsma said that could reach above 9.5 feet by Friday and Saturday.
Above 3,000 feet, Humboldt County is expected to see snow, though nearby Trinity County will be the more impacted region, though travel along state Route 299 to Redding this weekend could see chain advisories or a landslide.
“Be careful driving, especially around mountain passes. There could be some landslides on the roads and could close for some period of time,” Boomsma said.
A landslide did close state Route 199 in Del Norte County on Thursday near Hiouchi. As of Thursday afternoon, the highway remained closed along a stretch between 8 and 13 miles from U.S. Highway 101 in Del Norte County.
Find out more For more up-to-date information on weather conditions, go to weather.gov/eka/ .
For up-to-date information on the status of state highways, go to Caltrans’ QuickMap at https://quickmap.dot.ca.gov/ or use the app.
For more information on Pacific Gas and Electric Co. outages, go to https://pgealerts.alerts.pge.com/outage-tools/outage-map/ .
Jackson Guilfoil can be reached at 707-441-0506.
